instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.AVREF_SMC: What is AVREF_SMC? AVREF_SMC is a reference voltage provided to the SMC so that its sensors have a reference to work from, this should be 3.3v.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.
definitions.S4_PWR_EN: What is S4_PWR_EN? S4_PWR_EN turns on the S4 power rails. Signals ending in _EN enable whatever came before _EN in the signal name when the voltage of the signal is high. .
definitions.PM_SYSRST_L: What is PM_SYSRST_L? PM_SYSRST_L is a system reset signal present when it is low, _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be high for the system to exit reset mode & turn on properly. .
definitions.P3V3S3_EN: What is P3V3S3_EN? P3V3S3_EN is a signal that turns on the PP3V3_S3 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW: What is PM_BATLOW? PM_BATLOW is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on.

threads.title: SOLVED - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 12.56V <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 5V <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>: 3.3V <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.3V normal green/orange magsafe light
No further power rails present.

<CHIP>U1900</CHIP> seems ok, I can see 32KHz present, <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> present at 3.3V

Found a very small micro greenish spot near smc, cleaned it and reflowed SMC but nothing changes may need a replacement or reball.

Also, with SMC bypass all rails are present but no chime (CPU voltage is at 1.8V), witch may indicate a sensor or SMC issue.

Anything I could troubleshoot further before replacing SMC?

Thanks!

threads.title: SOLVED - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead
SOLVED - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead
threads.message:
First of all, be sure to have original 60/85W Magsafe 2 charger.
If liquid signs around SMC, better to rerball it.
Check <SIGNAL>AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> presence.
If OK, post <SIGNAL>CHGR_A</SIGNAL>/BMON values.
Also check resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>.

threads.title: SOLVED - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead
threads.message:
Thanks JohnB8812 and 2informaticos,
Didn't yet replaced smc.
Always using original 85W magsafe 2 for magsafe2 power jack boards.
Should had mention I've already checked <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> pin 17-18 and 27-28 they are normal 25,5V and 5,5V.
<SIGNAL>AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> is present at 3,3V.
<SIGNAL>CHGR_A</SIGNAL>/BMON are 0.031V and 0.053V respectively.

threads.title: SOLVED - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead
threads.message:
"<CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> pin 17-18 and 27-28 they are normal 25,5V and 5,5V."
I don't understand what this means...

Post basic signals for power on sequence in normal mode.

threads.title: SOLVED - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead
threads.message:
Sorry I was tired. I mean ohms instead of volts!
Resistance on <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> pins 17/18 is 25,5 ohms and 5,5ohms on pins 27/28.
thanks

threads.title: SOLVED - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead
threads.message:
Still waiting for signals.
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?

threads.title: SOLVED - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead
threads.message:
Hi, here are all values I noted.

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 16,5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.42V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12,56V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.3V

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 5V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> is missing (0V) so S4, S3 and S0 versions of PP5V are 0V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 3.3V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> 0,446V
<SIGNAL>S4_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> is missing (0V) because of <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5</SIGNAL> missing


<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> 0,23V
=<SIGNAL>P3V3S3_EN</SIGNAL> is missing (0V) because of <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> missing

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 2.02V (0,293 diode mode)

32KHz present at <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>

<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3.4v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 0.19V
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PM_SYSRST_L</SIGNAL> 2.09V

<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> 3.058V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL> 3.237V
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.328V

As I said earlier SMC bypass makes board to turn on with fan running high (no chime)
I see that <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW</SIGNAL> value is not normal... Also the presence of 2.02V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>.

Thanks!

threads.title: SOLVED - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead
threads.message:
See what happens without <CHIP>U8030</CHIP>.
Do you get any S3 voltage in normal mode in such case?

Check <SIGNAL>SMC_DCIN_VSENSE</SIGNAL> level.
Low <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> blocks PCH to start.
If you have correct charger for sure, then could be SMC issue; change it, for test.

threads.title: SOLVED - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead
threads.message:
Without <CHIP>U8030</CHIP> I had no S3 voltage.
<SIGNAL>SMC_DCIN_VSENSE</SIGNAL> voltage is 2,42V whitch looks ok according to the voltage divider.

Changed SMC and yes the board is back to life!

I am sure just a reball would have worked but I didn't bother, board is in immaculate condition with white indicators but still this little corrosion I saw was the only hint.
Thank you very much for your support.
